question: A.001 [1.0 point] {1.0} At the beginning of a reactor startup, Keff is 0.90 with a count rate of 30 CPS. Power is increased to a new, steady value of 60 CPS. The new Keff is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: (CR2/CR1) = (1-Keff1)/(1-Keff2)
Incorrect. Reference: (CR2/CR1) = (1-Keff1)/(1-Keff2)
Correct. Reference: (CR2/CR1) = (1-Keff1)/(1-Keff2)
Incorrect. Reference: (CR2/CR1) = (1-Keff1)/(1-Keff2)

question: A.002 [1.0 point] {2.0} Which ONE of the following is true concerning the differences between prompt and delayed neutrons?

answers.answer: a. Prompt neutrons account for less than one percent of the neutron population while delayed neutrons account for approximately ninety-nine percent of the neutron population
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Intro to Nuclear Eng, 2nd ed., pg. 73

answers.answer: b. Prompt neutrons are released during fast fissions while delayed neutrons are released during thermal fissions
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Intro to Nuclear Eng, 2nd ed., pg. 73

answers.answer: c. Prompt neutrons are released during the fission process while delayed neutrons are released during the decay process
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Lamarsh, Intro to Nuclear Eng, 2nd ed., pg. 73

answers.answer: d. Prompt neutrons are the dominating factor in determining the reactor period while delayed neutrons have little effect on the reactor period
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Intro to Nuclear Eng, 2nd ed., pg. 73

question: A.003 [1.0 point] {3.0} The effective neutron multiplication factor, Keff, is defined as:

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 149.
Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 149.
Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 149.
Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 149.

question: A.004 [1.0 point] {4.0} As the moderator temperature increases, the resonance escape probability:

answers.answer: a. increases, since the moderator becomes less dense
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 264.

answers.answer: b. decreases, since the time required for a neutron to reach thermal energy increases
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 264.

answers.answer: c. remains constant, since the effect of moderator temperature change is relatively small
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 264.

answers.answer: d. increases, since the moderator-to-fuel ratio increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 264.

question: A.005 [1.0 point] {5.0} Following a scram, the value of the stable reactor period is:

answers.answer: a. infinity, since neutron production has been terminated
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: b. about 50 seconds, because the rate of negative reactivity insertion rapidly approaches zero
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: c. about -10 seconds, as determined by the rate of decay of the shortest lived delayed neutron precursors
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: d. about -80 seconds, as determined by the rate of decay of the longest lived delayed neutron precursors
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

question: A.006 [1.0 point] {6.0} What are the three materials that are designed as moderators/reflectors, for your reactor?

answers.answer: a. Zirconium Hydride [ZrH2], Concrete, and Graphite
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

question: A.007 [1.0 point] {7.0} Which ONE of the following coefficients will be the first one to start turning reactor power after a power excursion from full power?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: GSTR Requal Exam 1/90
Incorrect. Reference: GSTR Requal Exam 1/90
Incorrect. Reference: GSTR Requal Exam 1/90
Incorrect. Reference: GSTR Requal Exam 1/90

question: A.008 [1.0 point] {8.0} Which ONE of the following is a correct statement concerning the factors affecting control rod worth?

answers.answer: a. The withdrawal of a rod causes the rod worth of the remaining inserted rods to increase
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 2nd ed., pg. 303 Glasstone and Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Eng., 3rd ed., Sect. 5.183

answers.answer: b. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth to increase in the center of the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 2nd ed., pg. 303 Glasstone and Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Eng., 3rd ed., Sect. 5.183

answers.answer: c. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth for periphery rods to decrease
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 2nd ed., pg. 303 Glasstone and Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Eng., 3rd ed., Sect. 5.183

answers.answer: d. As Rx power increases rod worth increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, 2nd ed., pg. 303 Glasstone and Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Eng., 3rd ed., Sect. 5.183

question: A.009 [1.0 point] {9.0} A step insertion of positive reactivity in a critical reactor causes a momentary rapid increase in the neutron population, known as a prompt jump. Which ONE of the following describes the cause of this increase?

answers.answer: a. An immediate increase in the prompt neutron population
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 240.

answers.answer: b. A shortening of the delayed neutron generation when power increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 240.

answers.answer: c. The positive reactivity insertion due to the rapid fuel temperature coefficient feedback
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 240.

answers.answer: d. The step insertion produces a rate of reactivity addition which exceeds the delayed neutron fraction, βeff
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, 3rd Edition, pg. 240.

question: A.010 [1.0 point] {10.0} Which ONE of the following factors is the most significant in determining the differential worth of a control rod?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

answers.answer: d. The amount of fuel in the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

question: A.011 [1.0 point] {11.0} Which ONE of the following conditions describes a critical reactor?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1984, § 3.3.4, pp. 3-23.
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1984, § 3.3.4, pp. 3-23.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1984, § 3.3.4, pp. 3-23.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1984, § 3.3.4, pp. 3-23.

question: A.012 [1.0 point] {12.0} Which ONE of the following will be the resulting stable reactor period when a $0.25 reactivity insertion is made into an exactly critical reactor core? (Assume a beta of .0070 and a lambda of .1 sec-1)

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, pg 239, Sec 5.28 T = (βeff - ρ)/(ρ λ)
Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, pg 239, Sec 5.28 T = (βeff - ρ)/(ρ λ)
Correct. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, pg 239, Sec 5.28 T = (βeff - ρ)/(ρ λ)
Incorrect. Reference: Glasstone & Sesonske, pg 239, Sec 5.28 T = (βeff - ρ)/(ρ λ)

question: A.013 [1.0 point] {13.0} The neutron microscopic cross-section for absorption (σa) of an isotope generally

answers.answer: a. increases as neutron energy increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: b. decreases as neutron energy increases
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: c. increases as target nucleus mass increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

answers.answer: d. decreases as target nucleus mass increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

question: A.014 [1.0 point] {14.0} Which one of the following describes the MAJOR contributor to the production and depletion of Xenon respectively in a STEADY-STATE OPERATING reactor?

answers.answer: a. Radioactive decay of Iodine  Radioactive Decay
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

answers.answer: b. Radioactive decay of Iodine  Neutron Absorption
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

answers.answer: c. Directly from fission  Radioactive Decay
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

answers.answer: d. Directly from fission  Neutron Absorption
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §§ 8.1 —8.4, pp. 8-3 — 8-14.

question: A.015 [1.0 point] {15.0} Which one of the following factors has the LEAST effect on Keff?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.3.2, p. 3-18.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.3.2, p. 3-18.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.3.2, p. 3-18.

answers.answer: d. Xenon and samarium fission products
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.3.2, p. 3-18.

question: A.016 [1.0 point] {16.0} Which ONE of the following is the reason for operating with thermal neutrons rather than fast neutrons?

answers.answer: a. As neutron energy increases, neutron absorption in non-fuel materials increases exponentially
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982

answers.answer: b. Probability of fission is increased since thermal neutrons are less likely to leak out of the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982

answers.answer: c. The absorption cross-section of U-235 is much higher for thermal neutrons
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982

answers.answer: d. The fuel temperature coefficient becomes positive as neutron energy increases
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982

question: A.017 [1.0 point] {17.0} The reactor supervisor tells you the reactor is shutdown with a shutdown margin of 12%. An experimenter inserts an experiment in the core and nuclear instrumentation increases from 100 counts per minute to 200 counts per minute. What is the new Keff of the reactor?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC Question
Correct. Reference: Standard NRC Question
Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC Question
Incorrect. Reference: Standard NRC Question

question: A.018 [1.0 point] {18.0} With the reactor on a constant period, which of the following changes in reactor power would take the LONGEST time?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: P = P0 et/τ ln(P/P0) = t/τ
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/τ ln(P/P0) = t/τ
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/τ ln(P/P0) = t/τ
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 et/τ ln(P/P0) = t/τ

question: A.019 [1.0 point] {19.0} During a fuel loading, as the reactor approaches criticality, the value of 1/M is plotted. Which ONE of the following describes the slope of the 1/M curve?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory

question: A.020 [1.0 point] {20.0} Which one of following is the correct reason that delayed neutrons enhance control of the reactor?

answers.answer: a. There are more delayed neutrons than prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.2.4, p. 3-12.

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons take longer to reach thermal equilibrium
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.2.4, p. 3-12.

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron generation time
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.2.4, p. 3-12.

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons born at higher energies than prompt neutrons & therefore have a greater effect
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 3.2.4, p. 3-12.
